Hello and welcome to the Morningstar Series
"Market Reaction". I'm Emma Wall and I'm joined

10.text:
today by Keith Wade, Chief Economist at the
Schroders to discuss the U.K. economy.

15.text:
So, we've heard this morning that Mark Carney
has decided to stay on as Bank of England

20.text:
Governor until June 2019 which is expected
to be sort of three months after Brexit actually

26.text:
happens. With this continuity at the head
of the Bank of England, what does it mean

29.text:
for monetary policy going forward?
Well, first of all I think it's good news,

33.text:
because Mark Carney is actually one of the
constants that we have in the U.K. at the

37.text:
moment, of course we have got a new government.
He will provide that continuity, but I think

43.text:
also he said he sees this as quite a challenging
time for the U.K. because of course we don’t

48.text:
know exactly what Brexit deal is going to
be.

51.text:
A lot of people have criticised Mark Carney
for being too gloomy about the economy. But

56.text:
I certainly think that there are lot of challenges
ahead and actually some of the problems which

61.text:
are being created by Brexit are still to come.
So, it’s good to know that there is somebody

65.text:
there who's got quite a bit of experience
and is prepared to put stimulus in to the

69.text:
economy when it's needed.
And one of the things which has led him to

72.text:
make the decision is that indeed the Monetary
Policy Committee as a whole, so far since

76.text:
Brexit is the rapid devaluation of sterling.
What do you expect from the currency in the

83.text:
future and how will this impact will we have
more QE because of it?

87.text:
Well, sterling has fallen a long way, and
of course in many ways that’s loosen monetary

92.text:
conditions for the Bank of England and in
some ways is doing Mark Carney's job for him

97.text:
which of course has created a base about how
much more does he need to do. Very difficult

102.text:
to know how far its going to go because of
course currencies have a tendency a bit of

106.text:
overshooting and falling very, very sharply
and then stabilising.

110.text:
It is true that the pound where it is today
is pretty competitive by pound standards.

115.text:
But you could argue that we need a competitive
pound because we have a big current account

119.text:
deficit and we need to sort of rebalance the
economy more towards overseas growth and to

125.text:
get that deficit under control. So, in some
ways you could say yeah, it's fallen a long

130.text:
way. People say oh, yes, it could fall a lot
further, but I wouldn’t be surprised if

134.text:
we saw a period of stability now and we began
to see some sort of improvement maybe in the

140.text:
traded good sector.
Looking further out it's difficult to know

143.text:
because unless we get an improvement in the
current account then the pound will always

147.text:
be vulnerable to further falls because we
do rely on what Mark Carney's called the kindness

151.text:
of strangers. Overseas investors willing to
buy the pound in order to keep it where it

157.text:
is.
Of course all the controversy surrounding

160.text:
Mark Carney is because of the comments he
made before we want to the polls. And that

164.text:
was that Brexit would be catastrophic for
the U.K. economy. The latest GDP figures last

170.text:
week showed that in the three months following
the Brexit vote actually the economy expanded

175.text:
by 0.5% instead of what was expected the contraction
of 0.1%. Can we expect this to continue or

184.text:
is that maybe too positive a view?
I think it's probably too positive. I mean

189.text:
it's certainly true the economy has performed
better than expected undoubtedly. I mean Mark

193.text:
Carney would say that some of that is because
of the action that he took to try and offset

197.text:
the negative effects. But I think when we
think back to before Brexit and look at the

201.text:
analysis that was done then.
The focus wasn’t really so much on the consumer

206.text:
being affected. It was much more on business
and capital spending and from what we can

211.text:
understand is that there has been a bit of
slowdown in CapEx and we think that could

215.text:
well continue because businesses is very uncertain
about exactly what Brexit will mean for them

222.text:
going forward.
It's not clear what trading arrangements we

224.text:
are going to have with our biggest partners
in Europe. It is not clear what the relationships

232.text:
would be between countries that have cross
border operations and so on. It's not clear

237.text:
what the regulation is going to be so everything
has kind of gone on to hold at the moment

240.text:
and of course that means that CapEx would
just be very flat and will be weaker. We don’t

245.text:
have a lot of data on CapEx. So we don’t
really quite know the full story.

249.text:
The consumer side, the consumer will be affected
but not really until later in the year and

256.text:
of course what we do know is happening is
that inflation is rising as a result of the

260.text:
falling of the pound which was one of the
things that we did expect to happen.

264.text:
So I think we're in a bit of phony war at
the moment. I mean people are drawing inferences

268.text:
and saying it has had much effect but that
full effect has not really been realized and

272.text:
we will see weaker business investment. We
will see weaker consumer spending over the

276.text:
next 12 months as the full Brexit effect comes
through.

279.text:
Keith, thank you very much.
Thank you.

281.text:
This is Emma Wall from Morningstar. Thank
you for watching.
